becoming old, and therefore in less good condition and less able to function well: When the cell can't divide any more, it becomes senescent, or terminally old. Disease is favoured by wet and damp conditions and is found most commonly on mature or senescent leaves. See
senescence
More examplesFewer examplesNumbers of senescent cells in baboons rose rapidly with age.These cells can produce new renal cells to replace the senescent and dead cells.Senescent cells are metabolically active but lack the capacity to replicate.
